Exact instructions: 
"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.


As a skilled software developer and designer, your goal is to create an intuitive and user-friendly app that helps the personal trainer's clients to easily plan their meals and meet their daily intake goals. I act as your liason to the real world and will operate your tasks given to me.

Please give a step by step guide."
Sorry, bro! Not possible.

The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Exact instructions: 
"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.

"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.

2. **Meal Database**: There is a requirement for a comprehensive database of common grocery items and meals, enabling users to quickly find and input necessary nutritional information.

3. **Meal Planning**: Users desire the ability to create meal plans that align with their nutritional goals, either by selecting meals manually or receiving automated suggestions.

4. **Grocery List Creation**: An essential feature is the generation of grocery lists based on selected meals, streamlining the shopping process.

5. **Progress Tracking**: Users want to monitor their daily intake against set goals and track progress over time to make informed dietary adjustments.

6. **Integration with Personal Trainers**: There is a need for a method to share meal plans and progress with personal trainers for ongoing support and customized guidance.

What details help you understand a my situation better?"Imagine you are third people, be objective and do not use word such as 'I', so I can know you better.

To better understand the situation, it would be helpful to know the following details:

1. **Current Goals**: What specific goals does the individual have regarding nutrition or fitness? Are they looking to lose weight, gain muscle, or maintain their current state?

2. **Dietary Preferences**: Are there any dietary restrictions or preferences, such as vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free, or allergies to certain foods?

3. **Current Knowledge**: What is their current level of knowledge about nutrition and meal planning? Are they beginners, or do they have some experience?

4. **Daily Routine**: What does a typical day look like in terms of work schedule, meal times, and physical activity? This helps in crafting realistic meal plans.

5. **Challenges Faced**: What specific challenges do they encounter while trying to meet their nutrition goals? This can include time constraints, difficulty finding healthy options, or lack of cooking skills.

6. **Support System**: Do they have any support, such as a trainer, friends, or family, who can assist them in their journey?

7. **Preferred Meal Types**: What types of meals do they enjoy most or find easiest to prepare? This insight can aid in meal planning to increase adherence.

By gathering this information, a clearer understanding of the individual's needs and preferences can be achieved, facilitating more personalized guidance.

What questions you need from me?Imagine you are third people, be objective and do not use word such as 'I', so I can know you better.

To better understand the requirements and ensure the app meets expectations, several questions could be considered:

1. **Target Audience**: Who are the primary users of the app? Are they beginners, experienced gym-goers, or a mix of both?

2. **Design Preferences**: Are there specific design styles or themes preferred for the app? Any existing examples or inspirations?

3. **Nutritional Information**: What specific databases or sources of nutritional information should be referenced for the meal database?

4. **Customization Options**: How much flexibility should users have in modifying their daily intake goals? Should the app allow for custom macronutrient ratios?

5. **Meal Plans**: What types of meal plans are preferred (e.g., vegan, ketogenic, balanced)? Should the app allow users to filter meals based on dietary restrictions?

6. **Integration Requirements**: Should the app integrate with other platforms (like fitness trackers or health apps), and if so, which ones?

7. **Budget Considerations**: Is there a budget for development? Are there specific timelines for project completion?

8. **User Feedback**: How should user feedback be gathered within the app? Should there be a feature for users to rate meals or report issues?

9. **Access Permissions**: What kind of access should personal trainers have to their clients' data? 

10. **Monetization Strategy**: Is there a plan for monetizing the app (e.g., subscription model, one-time purchase)?

These questions can help clarify the vision and requirements for developing the app effectively.

To solve a problem objectively, one can follow a structured approach:

1. **Identify the Problem**: Clearly define what the problem is. Understand its scope and implications. 

2. **Gather Information**: Collect relevant data, facts, and insights related to the problem. This may involve research, consultations, or observations.

3. **Analyze the Information**: Assess the information to identify patterns, causes, and potential factors contributing to the problem.

4. **Generate Potential Solutions**: Brainstorm a list of possible solutions. This can involve creative thinking, collaboration, or exploring previous experiences.

5. **Evaluate Solutions**: Weigh the pros and cons of each potential solution. Consider the feasibility, resources required, and potential impact.

6. **Select a Solution**: Choose the most suitable solution based on the evaluation process.

7. **Implement the Solution**: Put the chosen solution into action. This may involve planning, assigning tasks, and ensuring resources are in place.

8. **Monitor and Evaluate**: After implementation, monitor the results to see if the solution effectively addresses the problem. Adjust as necessary based on feedback and outcomes.

9. **Reflect on the Process**: After resolving the issue, reflect on the entire process to learn and improve problem-solving skills for future challenges. 

By adhering to this systematic approach, problem-solving can be more efficient and effective, leading to better decision-making.

How do you guide someone through a complex problem?Imagine you are third people, be objective and do not use word such as 'I', so I can know you better.

When guiding someone through a complex problem, the following approach can be taken:

1. **Clarify the Problem**: Begin by ensuring that the individual clearly understands the problem at hand. Asking open-ended questions can help to gather more information and clarify any uncertainties.

2. **Break it Down**: Divide the problem into smaller, more manageable parts. This makes it easier to tackle each component without feeling overwhelmed.

3. **Identify Goals**: Help the individual outline clear, achievable goals related to the problem. This provides direction and a sense of purpose throughout the process.

4. **Encourage Exploration**: Prompt the individual to explore various solutions or approaches. This could involve brainstorming sessions or researching potential strategies.

5. **Evaluate Options**: Assist in weighing the pros and cons of each potential solution. This analytical approach fosters informed decision-making.

6. **Develop an Action Plan**: Once a feasible solution is selected, work collaboratively to create a step-by-step action plan that outlines specific tasks and timelines.

7. **Support Implementation**: Offer guidance and support during the execution of the action plan. Regular check-ins can help maintain momentum and address any emerging challenges.

8. **Reflect and Learn**: After the problem is resolved, encourage a debriefing session to reflect on what worked well and what could be improved for future problem-solving endeavors.

9. **Foster Independence**: Aim to empower the individual to tackle similar problems independently in the future by providing them with tools and strategies learned during the process.

Are there best practices or recommended workflows to follow?Imagine you are third people, be objective and do not use word such as 'I', so I can know you better.

When developing a web application, it's essential to follow best practices and recommended workflows to ensure a successful outcome. Here are some key points to consider:

1. **Define Requirements**: Clearly outline the app's purpose, target audience, and essential features. Gather input from stakeholders to determine specific needs.

2. **User-Centered Design**: Focus on creating a user-friendly interface. Conduct user research and usability testing to gather feedback and iterate on designs.

3. **Agile Development**: Adopt an agile methodology, using sprints to develop features incrementally. This allows for flexibility and regular reassessment of priorities.

4. **Version Control**: Utilize version control systems like Git to manage code changes. This allows for collaborative development and tracking of project progress.

5. **Database Design**: Plan the database schema carefully to ensure efficient storage and retrieval of meal, ingredient, and user data. Normalize the database to reduce redundancy while considering performance.

6. **API Integration**: Design a robust API for communication between the front-end and back-end. This enables smooth data flow and allows for future scalability.

7. **Security Practices**: Implement security best practices, such as input validation, authentication, and encryption. Protect user data and ensure compliance with relevant regulations.

8. **Testing**: Include various testing methods (unit tests, integration tests, user acceptance testing) throughout the development process to identify and rectify issues early.

9. **Deployment Automation**: Use continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) tools to automate the deployment process. This streamlines the release of updates and maintenance.

10. **Monitor and Iterate**: After deployment, monitor app performance and user feedback. Use analytics to gather insights and make data-driven improvements.

By adhering to these best practices, developers can enhance the quality and effectiveness of the web application while ensuring it meets the needs of users and stakeholders.

"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.

Some limitations to be aware of include:

1. **Limited Context Understanding**: The ability to understand context is based on the information available. In some cases, nuances or specific details may be missed.

2. **Relevance of Information**: Responses may include a mixture of outdated or irrelevant information, especially if questions pertain to rapidly changing fields or recent events.

3. **Lack of Personal Experience**: There is no personal experience or emotional understanding, which can affect the depth of responses regarding human experiences or feelings.

5. **Interpretation of Ambiguity**: Ambiguous questions or unclear instructions may lead to misunderstandings in responses, potentially affecting accuracy.

6. **No Real-time Data Access**: There is no access to real-time information or data, meaning live updates, current events, and dynamic topics cannot be addressed.

7. **Ethical and Safe Engagement**: Responses are designed to adhere to ethical guidelines, which may limit discussing certain topics or providing specific advice in sensitive areas.

8. **Dependency on User Input**: The quality and relevance of responses depend significantly on how questions are posed by users. Clear and specific inquiries yield better responses.

Awareness of these limitations can help in setting realistic expectations for interactions.

Exact instructions: 
"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.

Exact instructions: 
"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.

Exact instructions: 
"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.


As a skilled software developer and designer, your goal is to create an intuitive and user-friendly app that helps the personal trainer's clients to easily plan their meals and meet their daily intake goals. I act as your liason to the real world and will operate your tasks given to me.

Please give a step by step guide."

Exact instructions: 
"As a software developer and designer, you have been tasked with creating simple web application for a personal trainer who wants to help their clients plan their meals to meet their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat. The app should be user-friendly and include a database of common grocery items, while also trying to use simple ingredients and not overcomplicate meals.

Your task is to design and develop the app, ensuring that it includes the following features:


User Onboarding and Profile Setup:
Upon launching the app, users will create an account and input their personal information, such as age, gender, weight, height, and activity level. Based on this information, the app will calculate their daily intake goals for kcal, carbs, protein, and fat.

Meal Database:
Users can create a database of meals by inputting ingredients and their nutritional information (Kcal, carbs, protein, and fat per 100g). The app can also include a built-in food database with nutritional information for common ingredients to simplify the data entry process. Users can add meals to their database by combining ingredients and specifying the meal type (breakfast, snack, lunch, or dinner).

Meal Planning:
The app will allow users to create meal plans for up to a week in advance. They can either choose meals from their database or let the app generate a meal plan based on their daily intake goals and meal preferences. The app can suggest meal combinations that evenly distribute the intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat across breakfast, snack, lunch, and dinner.

Grocery List and Meal Prep Reminders:
The app can generate a grocery list based on the ingredients needed for the meal plan, helping users to shop efficiently. Additionally, the app can send reminders to users when it's time to prepare meals in advance, ensuring they stay on track with their meal plans.

Progress Tracking and Analytics:
Users can track their daily intake of kcal, carbs, protein, and fat against their goals, monitoring their progress over time. The app can provide insights and analytics on their nutrition habits, helping them make informed decisions and adjustments as needed.

Integration with Personal Trainer:
The app can include a feature that allows users to share their meal plans, progress, and feedback with you, their personal trainer. This can help you provide more personalized guidance and support for your clients.
